oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Jim Bulleit face-to-face Interview Tape 2 of 2
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Record industry pioneer Jim Bulleit talks about his career in the music business, focusing on his WSM days, his record label Bullet Records, and his work as a booking agent. Discussion includes various artists from the Bullet catalogue; the contract arrangement for Bullet artists; WSM programming and personalities; Bullet distribution and promotion; opening the first record processing plant in Nashville; the end of Bullet Records; the Village and Delta record labels; his publishing interests; Lefty Frizzell and Don Law; overseeing the booking and the artists for the Louisiana Hayride; his work at Sun Records; the attempt to revive Bullet Records; and memories of Fred Rose.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Jim Bulleit
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: Side Two, Tape 2 of 2 (00:24) -- Continuation of The Louisiana Hayride conversation from previous interview tape. (2:10) -- Discussion of The Nashville Recording Studios on 4th Avenue. (4:20) -- John Rumble asks Jim Bulleit about his work with Sun Records in Memphis. (7:47) -- Conclusion of Jim Bulleit's Sun Studios situation. (8:31) Jim Bulleit says that Village and Delta "just died" when asked about what happened to those labels. (9:36) -- John Rumble asks Jim Bulleit about whether he ever tried to bring back Bullet Records. Jim Bulleit said he tried to release some music through someone in Florida in the 1960's, but the efforts were not successful. "It's awful hard to revive an old label, it's better to start a new label..." (10:43) -- John Rumble begins questioning Jim Bulleit about Red O'Donnell. Jim Bulleit said he asked Red directly to begin writing about music. (13:24) -- John Rumble asks about a name in connection with WSM from 1947, Les Bernard. (14:40) -- John Rumble changes the subject to Owen Bradley and his role in producing at Bullet Records. (15:49) -- Jim Bulleit clarifies for John Rumble that Francis Craig performed at the Hermitage, not the Maxwell House (where Beasley Smith performed). (17:00) -- John Rumble asks about the writing of "Near You". (19:26) -- John Rumble asks when the major labels came to Nashville according to Jim Bulleit. Jim Bulleit mentions that Castle Records was the first major studio to open. (21:13) -- John Rumble asks about Jim Bulleit's knowledge of Fred Rose.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Bulleit, Jim;
